pages.text: When given a redstone pulse, the $(l)Explosion Furnace$() will attempt to consume all $(l)Explosive$() and $(l)Reactant$() in its slots. If it succesfully did, it will produce an explosion and generate $(l)Explosive Power$() (or $(l)EP$()).$(br)The amount of $(l)EP$() generated is proportional to the amount of $(l)Explosive$() consumed and the $(l)Reactant$() used.

At the same time, an efficiency multiplier will be calculated depending on how far from the ideal proportions the quantities of $(l)Explosive$() and $(l)Reactant$() are $(o)(for Gunpowder and Sand it's 5:4)$().$(br)Being further from the ideal proportions results in more items to be lost in the process, while ideal proportions will result in no loss.

Then, inputs are run top to bottom. If there is enough $(l)EP$() to process one, it consumes the appropriate amount of $(l)EP$() and gets processed.$(br)If the recipe requires a $(l)Reagent$(), it will be consumed appropriately if present, and if not the input item will be lost.$(br2)$(l)Explosives$(), $(l)Reactants$(), inputs and $(l)Reagents$() can be inserted from any side by Hoppers and such, and outputs can be extracted from any side as well.
If the output slots are full while processing items, the excess items will be thrown in front of the $(l)Explosion Furnace$().
